title: How to Sharpen a Shovel

steps.headline: Gather the necessary materials.
steps.description: You will need steel wool, an emery cloth or a manufactured rust remover in order to prep the shovel for sharpening. You will also need a 10- or 12-inch mill bastard file. All of these materials can be found at your local hardware store.

steps.headline: Remove any rust from the shovel blade using the steel wool, emery cloth or rust remover.
steps.description: Gently scrub the surface of the shovel until any vestige of rust has been removed. This is an important step, as filing a rusty surface will dull the file resulting in ineffective sharpening.

steps.headline: Secure the shovel tightly in a vice or clamp it to the top of your workbench.
steps.description: Ensure the upper surface of the blade, or the concave side, is accessible. If you do not have access to a vice or clamps, grip the shovel between your knees and attempt to keep it as sturdy as possible.

steps.headline: Locate the sharp side of the shovel by running your finger lightly along the top, then the underside, of the blade.
steps.description: You will sharpen the leading edge, or the one that feels noticeably sharper to the touch.

steps.headline: File the leading edge with moderate pressure, pushing the file forward and sideways, at a uniform angle.
steps.description: You should form a bevel of about 70 degrees to the upper surface of the shovel. Avoid drawing the file backward.
